facts.text: The defendant-respondent owed money to the plaintiffs-appellants during the course of their business as commission agents for the defendant at Bombay.

Towards payment of those dues, the defendant drew two mudatti hundis in favour of the plaintiffs: one for Rs. 20,000 payable 61 days after date, and the other for Rs. 15,000 payable 121 days after date, total Rs. 35,000.
The plaintiffs endorsed the two hundis to G. Raghunathmal Bank and asked the Bank to credit their account with the amount on realisation.
On the date of their maturity, the Bank presented those hundis to the defendant, who dishonoured them.
The Bank returned the hundis to the plaintiffs.
The defendant did not pay the amount due under those documents on repeated demands by the plaintiffs.
Plaintiffs instituted suit for realisation of Rs. 39,615, principal with interest, in the Court of District Judge, Jodhpur, on January 4, 1949.

Defendant admitted execution of the hundis but alleged they were drawn for purchasing gold in future; plaintiffs did not send gold, so not honoured; denied owing money or hundis for debt payment; contended hundis without consideration.
Defendant pleaded hundis inadmissible as unstamped.
Issue No. 2: Whether the two hundis, being unstamped, were inadmissible in evidence? Onus on defendant.
Defendant examined as D.W.5: Did not receive gold; asked to return hundis but not returned; drew hundis Ex. P-1 and P-2 written in Roopchand's hand; no notice to honour.
Defendant's other witnesses D.Ws. 1,2,4 examined/cross-examined re terms of hundis and authorship.
Hundis referred to as Ex. P-1 and P-2 throughout evidence recording.

Learned Trial Judge held plaintiffs paid penalty; documents exhibited and marked under signatures; introduced in evidence; referred to and read by defendant's counsel; s.36 Stamp Act mandatory; decided issue against defendant; decreed suit in full with costs and future interest on September 26, 1952.

High Court on appeal: Noted hundis marked Ex. P-1, P-2 with 'Admitted in evidence' signed by Judge; Marwar Stamp Act 1914 ss.9,11 allowed admission on payment; but overlooked Marwar Stamp Act 1947 came into force; s.35 proviso (a) bars admission even on payment; s.36 not applicable as pure mistake; relied on Ratan Lal v. Dan Das; allowed appeal, dismissed suit, each party bear own costs, October 8, 1956.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) Constitution.

legal_issues.text: Whether the two hundis sued upon were admissible in evidence.
Whether the admission of the unstamped hundis in evidence by the Trial Court could be questioned by the High Court under s.36 of the Stamp Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Hundis properly admitted after payment of stamp duty and penalty; s.36 Stamp Act bars questioning admission.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 36 Stamp Act; Marwar Stamp Act 1914 ss.9,11

respondent_arguments.text: Hundis without consideration; drawn for future gold purchase not sent.

respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Stamp Act s.35 proviso (a); Marwar Stamp Act 1947

respondent_arguments.text: Admission by Trial Court was pure mistake; appellate court can correct it.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ratan Lal v. Dan Das, I.L.R. 1953 Raj. 833

court_reasoning.text: High Court misdirected on s.36 Stamp Act; s.36 categorical: once admitted in evidence, cannot be questioned at any stage except under s.61.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section 36 does not admit other exceptions.

court_reasoning.text: Question of admissibility to be decided when tendered; once court admits (rightly or wrongly), matter closed for parties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.35 penal; parties must be circumspect.

court_reasoning.text: Record shows hundis marked Ex. P-1, P-2 with endorsement 'admitted in evidence' signed by court; not inadvertent without applying mind; used in exam/cross-exam.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.36 comes into operation; not open to Trial Court, Appeal or Revision to go behind.

court_reasoning.text: Execution admitted by defendant; properly proved if required.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in refusing to act upon hundis.

holdings.text: Once a document admitted in evidence, such admission cannot be called in question at any stage on ground of insufficient stamping, per s.36 Stamp Act.
The two hundis were admissible in evidence; High Court erred in dismissing suit.

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court relied on it to hold admission was pure mistake and could be corrected on appeal; Supreme Court disagreed with application

statutes_cited.name: Indian Stamp Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s.35 bars admission of unstamped; s.36 bars questioning once admitted; s.61 exception not applicable

statutes_cited.name: Marwar Stamp Act, 1914
statutes_cited.relevance: Allowed admission on payment of duty/penalty when hundis executed

statutes_cited.name: Marwar Stamp Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Barred admission even on payment post-1947

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate granted for appeal to Supreme Court

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held High Court erred in law; reversed High Court judgment; restored Trial Court decree in favour of plaintiffs.
outcome.relief_granted: Suit decreed in full with costs and future interest as per Trial Court.
outcome.costs: Not specified in final order; High Court had directed each party bear own costs

key_quotes.text: "Where an instrument has been admitted in evidence, such admission shall not, except as provided in section 61, be called in question at any stage of the same suit or proceeding on the ground that the instrument has not been duly stamped."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Verbatim s.36 Stamp Act; core of holding

key_quotes.text: Section 36 is categorical in its terms that when a document has once been admitted in evidence, such admission cannot be called in question at any stage of the suit or the proceeding on the ground that the instrument had not been duly stamped.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Once a document has been marked as an exhibit in the case and the trial has proceeded all along on the footing that the document was an exhibit in the case and has been used by the parties in examination and cross-examination of their witnesses, s. 36 of the Stamp Act comes into operation.
key_quotes.speaker: court
